Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms, and (b) Pore size distribution curves of calcined Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(x) catalysts. Role of citric acid in enhancing aromatic hydrogenation performance in Ni-HPW/SiO2 catalysts Xiaofei Li Data curation Visualization Writing – original draft Investigation Methodology a Lili Geng Data curation Methodology Validation Visualization Writing – original draft b Haifeng Shi Data curation Validation Visualization b Songshou Ye Investigation Methodology Resources Validation a Ley Boon Sim Data curation Investigation Visualization Writing – review & editing c ⁎ Jinbao Zheng Formal analysis Investigation Methodology Validation Writing – review & editing a Nuowei Zhang Investigation Methodology Validation Visualization Writing – review & editing a Binghui Chen Conceptualization Funding acquisition Investigation Methodology Supervision Writing – review & editing a ⁎ a Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University, Xiamen, 361005, PR China Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University Xiamen 361005 PR China Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University, Xiamen, 361005, PR China b College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Changji University, Xinjiang, 831100, PR China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Changji University Xinjiang 831100 PR China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Changji University c School of Energy and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University Malaysia, Jalan Sunsuria, Bandar Sunsuria, 43900 Sepang, Malaysia School of Energy and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University Malaysia, Jalan Sunsuria Bandar Sunsuria Sepang 43900 Malaysia School of Energy and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University Malaysia, Jalan Sunsuria, Bandar Sunsuria, 43900 Sepang, Malaysia ⁎ Corresponding authors. In this study, we utilized a sol-gel method to prepare Ni-HPW/SiO2 catalysts with varying citric acid (CA):Ni molar ratios ranging from 0 to 5.0. The catalysts demonstrated different levels of activity in the hydrogenation of ethylbenzene, which correlated to their respective CA:Ni ratios. Introducing citric acid in the preparation process of nickel-based catalysts yielded mesopore formation and reduced NiO particle size, producing a more uniform NiO dispersion on SiO2, which was confirmed by BET, XRD, and TEM analyses. The results of H2-TPR, H2-TPD, NH3-TPD, and Py-IR analyses suggested that the addition of citric acid augmented the interaction between phosphotungstic acid (HPW), Ni species, and SiO2. Citric acid improved Ni species and HPW dispersion, fostering increased HPW-Ni species formation. This, in turn, generated additional electron-deficient Ni ions, stemming from semi-reduced HPW-Ni species, which acted as Lewis acid sites, enhancing Ni+ species effectiveness in activating aromatic rings. The better-dispersed, non-HPW-bound NiO, which, upon complete reduction to Ni, led to a substantial rise in H2 bond cleavage, thereby facilitating more hydrogen spillover. Overall, the infusion of citric acid into fabricating Ni-HPW/SiO2 catalysts sparked a significant surge in their aromatic hydrogenation ability. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Citric acid Aromatic hydrocarbon hydrogenation Ni-HPW/SiO2 catalysts Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In recent decades, environmental concerns regarding aromatic content reduction in distillate fuels have intensified. Among the methods employed, catalytic hydrogenation distinguishes itself as highly effective. Nickel-based catalysts are renowned for their effective aromatic hydrogenation capabilities, versatility in preparation conditions, and thus remain a preferred choice. HPW is a polyoxotungstate featuring the Keggin structure, composed of heteropoly anions with a basic structural unit of metal-oxygen octahedra [1,2]. HPW catalysts offer several advantages due to their enhanced acidity, environmental friendliness, and highly uniform acid site distribution, which allows for efficient operation under milder conditions [3]. Nevertheless, a notable drawback lies in their extremely low surface area, which is less than 10 m2/g. Therefore, it becomes imperative to focus on enhancing the dispersion of HPW on the catalyst support to achieve exceptional performance [4,5]. Some studies have showed that adding HPW to Ni-based catalysts increases hydrogen adsorption and acid site concentration, enhancing catalytic performance [6,7]. In our previous research, we prepared catalysts with varying HPW content using citric acid monohydrate (CA) as an additive (Ni/CA molar ratio of 1:1) and studied their impact on ethylbenzene hydrogenation activity [8]. Although citric acid was added during catalyst preparation, its comprehensive role in modifying catalyst structure, facilitating Ni-HPW interaction, and its effects on aromatic hydrogenation catalyst activity remain unexplored. Citric acid (CA) serves as a frequently employed chelating ligand in the preparation of hydrogenation catalysts to achieve high dispersion of active species, when added to hydrogenation catalysts, forms large clusters around active species, enhancing their dispersion by preventing aggregation through steric hindrance [9,10]. This leads to smaller particle sizes and improved resistance to sintering upon calcination. However, excessive CA can result in its polymerization, potentially reducing dispersion due to increased solution viscosity, indicating a balance is necessary in CA concentration [11]. A study conducted by Yoshida and colleagues [12] unveiled that the inclusion of citric acid in the catalyst preparation process led to an enhanced dispersion of Ni on SiO2, thereby mitigating metal species aggregation, which has been known to impair catalytic activity. Nakazono et al. [13] reported a significant improvement in the acetoin hydrogenation performance of the Ni/SiO2 catalyst through the incorporation of citric acid in its synthesis. This enhancement was attributed to citric acid facilitation of the dispersion of metal species on silica supports. Previous investigations have revealed that citric acid can enhance metal-support interactions, exemplified in xCA-Ni/Y2O3 catalysts [10]. Furthermore, it demonstrates the capability to regulate particle size and Ni species dispersion. Notably, the introduction of citric acid in sulfide CoMo/Al2O3 catalysts results in a substantial reduction in particle size, a favorable outcome contributing to improved catalyst dispersion [14]. It is worth noting, however, that excessive citric acid loading can lead to undesirable active phase agglomeration [15]. In addition to its conventional applications as an organic solvent or activator in the sol-gel process [16,17], the incorporation of citric acid during catalyst preparation significantly influences the catalyst pore structure, facilitating a transition from a microporous to a mesoporous configuration [18,19]. While the use of citric acid in catalyst preparation plays an important role in improving catalyst performance, its concurrent use with HPW remains uncommon in industry. In this study, we synthesized Ni-HPW/SiO2 catalysts with varying citric acid concentrations using the sol-gel method, evaluating their ethylbenzene hydrogenation performance. A comprehensive investigation was carried out to examine the influence of the CA loading amount on the catalyst structural morphology. This, in turn, resulted in changes in the catalyst surface acidity, the electron-deficient state of Ni species, and hydrogen adsorption capacity. This provided a deep understanding of the impact of CA loading on catalytic performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents Citric acid monohydrate (C6H8O7·H2O) and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O) was purchased from Xilong Scientific Co., Ltd. Phosphotungstic acid (H3PW12O40) (HPW), ethylbenzene and ethyl cyclohexane were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. All reagents were of analytical reagent grade and used without further treatment. Chromatographic air, high purity hydrogen (>99.999 %) and high purity nitrogen (>99.999 %) were purchased from Fuzhou Xinhang Industrial Gas Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst Preparations The Ni-HPW/SiO2 catalysts were prepared using the sol-gel method. A beaker containing an appropriate amount of citric acid, 5.3 mL of 1 mol/L nickel nitrate solution, and 16.7 mL of TEOS was stirred at 60 °C for 30 min. Next, 0.25 g of HPW was added to the hot solution and stirred to form a gel. The gel was dried overnight at 120 °C and calcined in air at 400 °C for 4 h in a static furnace. The sample was then sieved through a 40–60 mesh. The Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(x) catalysts were obtained by varying the CA content to achieve different CA:Ni molar ratios (x = 0, 0.5, 1.5, 2.2, 3.0, 5.0), while keeping the nickel nitrate concentration constant at 6.3 %. 2.3 Catalyst characterization TG analysis was conducted using the STA-449-F5 thermogravimetric analyzer at a ramping rate of 5 °C/min under the flow of air. FT-IR spectroscopy data were acquired using a Bruker V70FT-IR spectrometer over a frequency range of 400–4000 cm−1 with 32 scans at a resolution of 4 cm−1 (Fig. S1 in the supplementary information). Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured volumetrically in a liquid nitrogen cold trap using a Micromeritics Tristar-3020 instrument. The samples were degassed for 3 h at 300 °C under vacuum to eliminate water and impurities before adsorption measurement. The crystal structure and phase purity of the catalysts were determined by powder XRD analysis using a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffraction instrument equipped with Cu Kα radiation. TEM observations were carried out on a Tecnai G2 F30 high-resolution transmission electron microscope at 300 kV. H2-TPR experiments were conducted using a Micromeritics Auto Chem II 2920 apparatus. The samples (50 mg) were pretreated at a rate of 10 °C/min to 300 °C for 1 h in a flow of Ar (20 mL/min), and then cooled to ambient temperature. Next, the samples were switched to a H2/Ar flow (5 % H2) and heated at a rate of 10 °C/min to 800 °C. The online gas chromatograph equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to detect H2 desorption. H2-TPD measurements were performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 analyzer. A U-shaped quartz reactor tube was filled with 0.2 g of the catalyst sample. All samples were pretreated in Ar (30 mL/min) at 400 °C for 2 h, followed by treatment in H2 (50 mL/min) for 1 h. After cooling to 50 °C, an H2 (50 mL/min) was passed over the samples for 2 h. Then the samples were swept with Ar (30 mL/min) for 1 h to remove any physiosorbed molecules. Finally, the desorption step was carried out from 50 °C to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in a flow of Ar (30 mL/min). The mass spectrometry (MS) equipment was used to monitor the desorbed products. NH3-TPD was performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 analyzer. The catalyst sample (0.2 g) was pretreated in Ar (30 mL/min) at 400 °C for 2 h and then in H2 (50 mL/min) for 1 h. After cooling the sample down to 120 °C, an NH3/Ar mixture (50 mL/min, 5 % NH3) was passed over the samples for 2 h. Then, the samples were swept with Ar (30 mL/min) for 1 h to remove any physiosorbed molecules, and finally, the desorption was performed from 50 °C to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min with Ar (30 mL/min). The desorbed products were monitored by MS equipment. Py-IR data were measured using a Thermo-Nicolet Nexus spectrometer equipped with a liquid-nitrogen-cooled mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detector with 32 scans at a resolution of 4 min−1. The samples were pressed into circular flakes (approximately 15 mg, Φ12 mm) and treated in H2/N2 (10/90) at 400 °C in an IR cell for 2 h. The background spectrum was taken at the desired temperature followed by evacuation. While cooling to 100 °C, the samples were exposed to pyridine vapor for 10 min. Then, the spectra were recorded after evacuation. XPS patterns were collected using a VG MiltiLab 2000 spectrometer with Mg Kα radiation and a multichannel detector. The XPS spectra of all elements were corrected with the binding energy of C1S (Eb=284.6 eV) as an internal standard. The experimental protocols details were described in the supplementary information. 2.4 Activity studies The catalytic performance was evaluated using a high-pressure fixed-bed reactor, which enabled in-situ catalyst roasting, reduction, and testing with online product detection. A 0.2 g catalyst sample was packed into a quartz tube and placed inside a stainless-steel reaction tube. A thermocouple was inserted into the quartz tube from the top of the stainless-steel tube to ensure that the temperature sensor was located directly above the catalyst bed (Fig. S2 in the supplementary information). The catalyst was prepared for use by initially reducing it with high-purity hydrogen at a flow rate of 50 mL/min and a heating rate of 5 °C/min from room temperature to 400 °C for 4 h, followed by cooling to room temperature. The catalytic activity of the reduced catalyst was then evaluated under the following conditions: 1.0 MPa, 160 °C, a liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) of 26.0 h−1, and an H2/ethylbenzene volume ratio of 500. A Series II liquid phase pump was utilized to introduce the reaction feed into the reaction tube, which enabled precise flow control ranging from 0.001 to 5 mL/min. The reaction products were analyzed using gas chromatography with a SE-54 capillary column (50 m × 0.32 mm) on a GC2060 instrument. The injector temperature and six-way valve temperature were set at 150 °C and 160 °C, respectively. The column furnace was maintained at 60 °C, and the FID detector temperature was set to 150 °C (Fig. S3 in the supplementary information). The conversion of ethylbenzene (X) and the selectivity of ethylcyclohexane (S) were calculated using the following equations: X = ∑ i n f i A i f eb A eb + ∑ i n f i A i × 100 % S = f ec A ec ∑ i n f i A i × 100 % Where Aeb, Aec, and Ai are the peak areas of ethylbenzene, ethylcyclohexane, and each product, respectively. feb, fec, and fi are the correction factor of ethylbenzene, ethylcyclohexane, and each product, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity Table 1 and Fig. 1 summarize the catalyst performance under various conditions. Ethylbenzene, recognized for its stability at 160 °C [8], was observed in this study to undergo predominantly a single hydrogenation reaction at this temperature, resulting in ethylcyclohexane as the main product. Under the specified reaction conditions, all the catalysts we tested exhibited nearly 100 % selectivity towards ethylcyclohexane, a finding that aligns with several reports in the literature [20–23]. The Ni-HPW/SiO2 catalyst fabricated without citric acid displays low hydrogenation activity, resulting in a mere 3.25 % conversion of ethylbenzene. However, the addition of citric acid boosts hydrogenation activity, but with increasing citric acid concentration, activity declines. Among all catalysts tested, Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(2.2) displays the highest activity, achieving 78.75 % conversion after a 2-hour reaction. Meanwhile，the Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(2.2) catalyst sustains a high conversion (>95 %) at a lower space velocity of 10.6 h−1, At a higher space velocity of 26.0 h−1, the conversion experiences a minor decrease, yet remains stable throughout an 8-hour test run (Fig. 1). These results underscore the impact of citric acid on Ni-HPW/SiO2 hydrogenation activity, with an optimal citric acid dosage achieving high activity levels. 3.2 TG profiles of catalysts Fig. 2 depicts thermogravimetric analysis (TG) results for Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(x) catalysts. Weight loss exhibited a phase-shift pattern attributed to lattice water loss below 150 °C and the decomposition of bulk citric acids or citric acid-Ni complexes between 150–350 °C [19,24,26,27]. At temperatures exceeding 350 °C, weight loss is influenced by the interaction between decomposed citric acid and silicone gel, as well as the decomposition of phosphotungstic acid [19,25–27]. The TG analysis highlights the predominance of bulk citric acids, indicating the need for Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy to assess the calcination impact on citric acid and subsequent catalyst physicochemical characteristics. 3.3 IR spectra of catalysts Fig. 3 presents the FT-IR analysis of Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(x) catalysts. All samples exhibit a strong absorption peak at around 3400 cm−1, attributed to crystal water [19]. This peak becomes weaker in the calcined samples. In uncalcined samples, there is an absorption peak at 1730 cm−1 representing bulk carboxyl groups [24]. The concentration of these groups increases with higher citric acid levels but disappears after calcination. This suggests that almost all bulk citric acid decomposes at 400 °C 4-hour calcination, consistent with thermogravimetric analysis. The weak absorption peaks at 960 cm−1 and 1630 cm−1 correspond to Si-OH stretching and SiO-H bending vibrations [26]. These peaks nearly vanish in citric acid-free samples after calcination but remain and intensify as the citric acid content grows. It is suggested that citric acid may form stable complexes with silicon ions, potentially creating a protective layer that could help prevent Si-OH and SiO-H groups from dehydrating during calcination. The sharp peak at 1390 cm−1 corresponds to Ni(NO3)2 species [24]. As citric acid content increases, its intensity decreases, indicating interaction between nickel and citric acid. After calcination, this peak nearly disappears, confirming Ni(NO3)2 decomposition for the formation of NiO. Absorption peaks of P-O asymmetric stretching (1080 cm−1) and Si-O-Si stretching (1200 cm−1) overlap with the O-Si-O stretching peak at 1100 cm−1, confirming the interaction between HPW and silicone gel [24,28]. With increasing citric acid concentration, these peaks intensify in the calcined catalyst. This indicates an enhanced HPW-SiO2 interaction or a higher presence of O-Si-O and Si-O-Si on the catalyst surface. Both FT-IR and TG analyses confirm that most Ni(NO3)2 and citric acid in the calcined Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(x) catalyst undergo decomposition. 3.4 Textural properties of catalysts We assessed the effect of citric acid on the textural properties of the calcined Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(x) catalysts through nitrogen physisorption measurements. The N2 isotherms display Type IV(a) adsorption behavior with notable hysteresis loops ( Fig. 4a) [29], attributed to variations in condensation and evaporation pressures within the catalyst pore network. Evaporation within the catalyst pores occurs via pore blocking and cavitation. These catalysts typically exhibit a mesoporous structure [30]. Moreover, the hysteresis loop size increases with higher citric acid content. Analysis of pore size distribution (Fig. 4b) reveals that citric acid enlarges catalyst pore size, which grows with increased citric acid concentration. Specific surface area and pore volume ( Table 2) also increase correspondingly. Isotherms with CA/Ni ratios of 0.5, 1.0, and 1.5 show smaller hysteresis loops, indicating more mesoporous structures with smaller average pore sizes and some microporous structures. For CA/Ni ratios of 2.2 and 3.0, isotherms exhibit H4-type characteristics, signifying cavitation dominance. The isotherm at a CA/Ni ratio of 5.0 combines H3-type and H2(b)-type characteristics, showing pore blocking as the dominant mechanism due to the larger average pore size (Dpore = 5.2 nm). During the citric acid-assisted sol-gel process, amorphous citric acid envelops the silica gel polymer network. Typically, one citric acid molecule corresponds to every 7–8 Si atoms. Citric acid molecules form hydrogen bonds with some surface silanol groups, while others remain unbound. These hydrogen bonds, during calcination, are too weak to prevent silanol-attached citric acid from decomposing. This decomposition results in pore formation while preserving the silica gel structure [24,26,31]. In summary, citric acid contributes to increased pore volume and specific surface area, aligning with previous findings. 3.5 Crystal structure and morphology The XRD patterns in Fig. 5 show that NiO is the primary nickel form in the Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(x) catalysts, with Ni3(PO4)2 and NiWO4 also present. The peaks at 2θ = 37.3°, 43.4°, 63.0°, 75.5°, and 79.5° correspond to the cubic crystal structure of NiO (JCPDS: 47–1049). Interestingly, with the increase in citric acid content, the intensity of the NiO peak first decreases and then increases. At lower CA/Ni ratios, the calcination decomposition of citric acid is not sufficient to effectively disperse nickel species, leading to significant surface aggregation and incomplete crystal structures. As a result, a higher and broader NiO crystal X-ray diffraction is observed, indicating larger NiO particles with poor dispersion. When the CA/Ni ratio is 2.2, the decomposition of citric acid is moderate and effectively disperses the nickel species, with the weakest peak observed in Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(2.2). This suggests that a CA/Ni ratio of 2.2 results in the best dispersion of NiO and the smallest surface particle size, aligning with the Scheller calculations in Table 2. As the CA/Ni ratio further increases, excessive citric acid occupies the catalyst surface and decomposes violently during calcination, causing NiO around citric acid to agglomerate more easily and grow into larger NiO crystals, resulting in sharper NiO peaks. Similarly, the HPW diffraction peak follows this trend, but its weakest intensity is seen in Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(3.0). This suggests that an appropriate citric acid concentration can enhance the dispersion of active components in the carrier, thereby improving catalyst hydrogenation activity. 3.6 TEM characterization Fig. 6 displays TEM images and size distributions of oxidized Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(x) samples. Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(0.0) and Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(0.5) catalysts show severe agglomeration. However, increased citric acid concentration leads to more uniform NiO dispersion. Particle size decreases initially and then expands, consistent with XRD. In heterogeneous catalysis, catalyst performance is significantly influenced by the size of supported metal particles and their interaction with the support. Smaller nickel particles, due to their increased surface area, enhance the number of active sites for substrate adsorption and activation, leading to improve conversion [32–35]. Additionally, smaller particles demonstrate better interaction with the support, manifesting a constraining effect. This interaction effectively limits the migration and aggregation of the active material particles, ensuring good resistance to sintering and thereby maintaining stable catalytic performance [36]. Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(2.2) has the smallest particle size and best distribution, exhibiting the highest activity with 78.75 % conversion. The results indicate that citric acid incorporation benefits particle size and Ni species dispersion tuning. 3.7 Reduction of surface particles on catalysts H2-TPR experiments examined the citric acid effect on NiO-HPW interaction. Previous studies indicate NiO reduction at 250–400 °C for bulk (region Ⅰ in Fig. 7) and 400–600 °C for NiO interacting with HPW and silica [37,38] (region Ⅱ in Fig. 7). HPW reduction occurs above 600 °C [8,39] (region Ⅲ in Fig. 7). Citric acid increase up to CA/Ni ratio of 2.2 reduced bulk NiO peak intensity and shifted it rightward, indicating enhanced NiO-HPW and NiO-silica interactions. To demonstrate how citric acid affects catalyst reducibility and the interactions between NiO, HPW, and the carrier, we performed Gaussian fitting and integrated the reduction peak areas in the H2-TPR curves of various catalysts showed in Fig. 7. Fig. 8a illustrates this integration process, and Fig. 8b displays the ratios of free-state (bulk) NiO to NiO interacting with HPW and the carrier in catalysts across different CA/Ni values post-integration. From Fig. 8b, it is observed that when CA/Ni is less than 2.2, as the CA/Ni value increases, the reduction peak area of free-state NiO gradually decreases, while that of NiO interacting with HPW and the carrier (HPW-NiO) gradually increases. This indicates a gradual transformation of free-state (bulk) NiO into NiO interacting with HPW and the carrier, making the NiO harder to reduce and signifying a gradual decrease in the reducibility of NiO species. When CA/Ni ratio is 2.2, the proportion of hard-to-reduce NiO in the catalyst is the highest, coinciding with the highest catalyst activity. The hard-to-reduce Ni species (Niδ+) act as Lewis acid sites, better adsorbing and activating ethylbenzene, while reduced free-state NiO more effectively adsorbs hydrogen species. When CA/Ni is greater than 2.2, the opposite trend is observed, with both forms of NiO transforming complementarily as the CA/Ni value increases. This indicates that the balance and synergistic effect between hard-to-reduce NiO and free-state NiO are key to enhancing catalytic hydrogenation activity. 3.8 Hydrogen spillover ability on the surface of catalysts The hydrogen adsorption and desorption capacity of the catalysts, crucial for hydrogenation performance, were analyzed in Fig. 9. H2 desorption peaks were observed at both low (100–150 °C) and high temperatures (above 350 °C). Increasing citric acid concentration, particularly when CA/Ni ≤ 2.2, shifted the high-temperature desorption peak to lower temperatures. This suggests an improved dehydrogenation activity and hydrogen spillover ability, aligning with the enhanced hydrogenation performance. When the CA/Ni ratio is 3.0 and 5.0, the catalysts possess larger specific surface areas (as known from BET results) and a greater amount of HWP structure (as indicated by infrared spectroscopy results). In the presence of a higher concentration of strong acids, the adsorbed hydrogen species more readily overflow onto the high specific surface area of the catalysts. Therefore, at higher temperatures, more intense peaks can be observed [40,41]. 3.9 Surface acid properties NH3-TPD analysis assessed acid site quantity and strength on Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(x) catalysts in Fig. 10. The catalyst surfaces primarily featured weak and medium-strength acid sites, evidenced by a significant NH3 desorption peak between 150–350 °C. A smaller quantity of strong acid sites, with a peak above 450 °C, was also present. The HPW-Ni interaction accounted for the coexistence of these weak and strong acid sites [8]. Increasing CA concentration caused a shift of the desorption peak from low to high temperatures and another from above 450 °C to lower temperatures. While this indicated changes in acid strength, the overall increase in acidity at weak acid sites overshadowed the impact on strong acid sites. Citric acid was found to influence the HPW-Ni interaction and the ratio of weak to strong acid sites. To understand how acid site quantity affects catalytic activity, we employed Gaussian fitting and area integration to calculate the proportions of various acid site strengths from NH3 desorption peaks. Fig. 11a illustrates this fitting and integration process, and Fig. 11b presents the area ratios of weak, medium-strong, and strong NH3 desorption peaks in catalysts across different CA/Ni values. Fig. 11b reveals that when CA/Ni is less than 2.2, as the CA/Ni ratio increases, the area of weak acid peaks gradually decreases, and the area of medium-strong acid peaks increases, indicating a transformation of weak acids into medium-strong acids and an overall increase in catalyst acidity. Conversely, when CA/Ni is greater than 2.2, the opposite trend is observed. The highest proportion of medium-strong acid and the lowest proportion of weak acid occur at a CA/Ni ratio of 2.2, where both acid strength types transform complementarily as the CA/Ni value increases. Studies have showed that the delicate balance between the number of medium-strength acid sites and metal sites on the catalyst surface determines catalytic activity [42]. Interestingly, the Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(2.2) catalyst in this study with the highest proportion of medium-strong acids also exhibits excellent catalytic activity, indicating that medium-strong acids play a key role in enhancing the catalytic activity for ethylbenzene hydrogenation. These medium-strong acids primarily originate from electron-deficient Ni species interacting with HPW, consistent with the trend in the ratio of free NiO to hard-to-reduce NiO in Fig. 8b. This suggests that the balance between acid and metal sites on the catalyst surface is crucial for its performance. Numerous studies have established that the type and strength of solid acids significantly influence the performance of nickel-based catalysts [8,39,43,44]. Likewise, an increase in Lewis acid content has been linked to the electron-deficient properties of metals in similar catalysts [45,46]. Py-IR spectroscopy ( Fig. 12) showed the catalyst surfaces were predominantly Lewis acidic, with a peak at 1448 cm−1, and contained a smaller quantity of Lewis-Brønsted mixed acids, represented by a peak at 1488 cm−1. The Brønsted acid peak at 1542 cm−1 was absent in all catalysts except Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(0.0), which is consistent with the literature [8]. Nevertheless, the quantity of Lewis acids and Lewis-Brønsted mixed acids exhibited a volcano-like trend as citric acid concentration increased in the catalysts. The XRD pattern in Fig. 5 reveals increased HPW-Ni interactions through the formation of Ni3(PO4)2 and NiWO4. This arises from HPW H+ replacement by Ni cations (HPW-Ni species), leading to more reduction-resistant Ni cations, as seen in Fig. 7 H2-TPR results. Consequently, the electron-deficient state of surface Ni species is a result of partial reduction, primarily due to HPW-Ni interactions preventing complete reduction. These partially reduced species, which are a portion of the catalyst, serve as additional Lewis acid sites. This enhancement in Lewis acid sites is responsible for increasing the ability of Niδ+ species to activate aromatic rings. 3.10 Metal characteristics and XPS characterization of catalysts As per the XPS standard manual, specific energy binding peaks indicate Ni0 (851.9–852.8 eV), NiO (853.5–854.4 eV), and NiWO4 (857.2–858.0 eV). Fig. 13 and Table 3 present the metallic properties of reduced Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(x) catalysts. The Ni0/Ni2+ ratio generally decreases with increased citric acid loading, except for Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(0). The W/Si atomic ratio follows a similar trend. Notably, Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(0.5) and Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(1.5) exhibit a higher Ni0/Ni2+ ratio compared to Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(0), indicating the role of citric acid in facilitating Ni2+ reduction within a specific loading range (<2.2), beyond which Ni2+ reduction becomes more challenging. Table 2 indicates that increased citric acid loading improves the catalyst textural properties, enhancing HPW dispersion within internal pores. This, however, results in a lower surface concentration of HPW, as seen in the W/Si atomic ratio in Table 3 (except for Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(0)). The catalysts, with higher citric acid loading, display enhanced dispersion of NiO and HPW, increasing their interaction. This leads to a higher content of strongly interacting NiO species with HPW and a reduced content of free NiO species. Consequently, there is a decreasing trend in Ni0/Ni2+ on the catalyst surface after hydrogen reduction (Table 3), signifying that higher citric acid loading makes the reduction of Ni2+ species more challenging, consistent with H2-TPR results. Citric acid loading significantly influences surface Ni0/Ni2+ and W/Si ratios. Electron-deficient nickel in the partially reduced part of Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(x) catalysts increases Lewis acid content for aromatic ring activation. It results from nickel ion substitution in HPW strong acid sites, forming nickel-substituted phosphotungstic acid. Part of the nickel species that was completely reduced contribute to hydrogen spillover. A balance between hydrogen spillover and aromatic ring activation, as indicated by the Ni0/Ni2+ ratio at CA/Ni 2.2, ensures high catalytic activity. 4 Conclusions Utilizing a citric acid-modified sol-gel approach for the preparation of Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(x) catalysts has unveiled the pivotal role of citric acid in enhancing surface area, increasing pore volume, and improving the dispersion of Ni species on the support. This, in turn, led to a reduction in NiO particle size and the reinforcement of HPW-Ni interactions as illustrated in Fig. 14. These enhanced interactions result in a fraction of the Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(x) catalysts resisting complete reduction, leading to an augmentation in the quantity of Lewis acid sites, confirmed by XPS analysis. The higher presence of Lewis acid sites significantly enhances the activation capacity for ethylbenzene. Moreover, the more uniformly dispersed non-HPW-bound NiO significantly enhances H2 bond cleavage upon reduction to Ni, consequently promoting greater hydrogen spillover. These inherent contributions of citric acid to Ni-HPW/SiO2-CA(x) catalysts in the context of aromatic hydrogenation underscore its efficacy in catalysis. Nonetheless, this study suggests that the optimum Ni to CA molar ratio falls within the range of 1:1.5 to 2.2. coredata.dc:description: In this study, we utilized a sol-gel method to prepare Ni-HPW/SiO2 catalysts with varying citric acid (CA):Ni molar ratios ranging from 0 to 5.0. The catalysts demonstrated different levels of activity in the hydrogenation of ethylbenzene, which correlated to their respective CA:Ni ratios. Introducing citric acid in the preparation process of nickel-based catalysts yielded mesopore formation and reduced NiO particle size, producing a more uniform NiO dispersion on SiO2, which was confirmed by BET, XRD, and TEM analyses. The results of H2-TPR, H2-TPD, NH3-TPD, and Py-IR analyses suggested that the addition of citric acid augmented the interaction between phosphotungstic acid (HPW), Ni species, and SiO2. Citric acid improved Ni species and HPW dispersion, fostering increased HPW-Ni species formation. This, in turn, generated additional electron-deficient Ni ions, stemming from semi-reduced HPW-Ni species, which acted as Lewis acid sites, enhancing Ni+ species effectiveness in activating aromatic rings. The better-dispersed, non-HPW-bound NiO, which, upon complete reduction to Ni, led to a substantial rise in H2 bond cleavage, thereby facilitating more hydrogen spillover. Overall, the infusion of citric acid into fabricating Ni-HPW/SiO2 catalysts sparked a significant surge in their aromatic hydrogenation ability.
coredata.dc:title: Role of citric acid in enhancing aromatic hydrogenation performance in Ni-HPW/SiO2 catalysts
